nodes.bodyText: nit: lets move it before the assignment
public
Do we support empty files? Or do we want to consider them as invalid?
TestHiveIntegrationSmokeTest::testInsertPartitionedBucketedTableFewRows creates an split with fileSize = 0, I haven't figured out when that could happen
It doesn't feel like we need a class to read a footer. How about we add a simple static method to the PageFilePageSource that does just that?
We may extend the footer later.  For example, to include compression code
You can wrap the input stream with the InputStreamSliceInput and use the #getLong method that reads longs in LITTLE_ENDIAN
What if there's no stripes? It feels like this should be initialized as empty.
And stripe offset should be added before adding a new stripe
As this will effectively add an offset for non existing stripe

I see what are you doing. You are treading the footer as a "stripe" adding the last offset as an offset of the footer. It would work, but it is a little confusing. How about we make it more explicit. Let's add offsets only for existing stripes, and then add the size of the footer in bytes as a last long of the file. Similar to ORC.

I was planning to draw a footer design picture before adding you to review, but you get the idea correctly !

Like ORC,  stripOffset is the beginning of a stripe, thus offSet start from 0
Use N + 1  long to represent N stripes has advantage of labeling the end of last stripe.
The last stripeOffset is offset of footer, it is used for the same purpose as size of footer, but has advantage of avoiding calculation last stripe size. Otherwise, lastStripeSize = fileSize - beginningOfLastStripe - stripeSize
Maybe we should use size of footer instead of beginning of footer to be consistent with ORC
To me the simplest format would be an offset and length. Why try to do fancy things to derive where things are and how long they are when space is not at a premium?

To me the simplest format would be an offset and length. Why try to do fancy things to derive where things are and how long they are when space is not at a premium?

Length is inferred from difference of adjacent offset, @andri was suggesting to use footer size to replace footer offset.
Let's move the getReadStartAndLength  here

nodes.bodyText: Instead of keeping track of readBytes you can use ByteStreams#limit
Thank you,  I get rid of readBytes using InputStreamSliceInput.position()
How about passing an already positioned and limited input stream? (doing inputStream.seek(readStart); and ByteStreams#limit outside)? If you do that then most likely you won't even need this class.
Keep using InputStreamSliceInput to reuse function readSerializedPage(SliceInput)

InputStreamSliceInput is inefficient about readBytes. We can eliminate some copying for free there. Depending on how often we use it in Presto it would be a tiny amount of free performance.
It copies to its internal buffer and then copies to the output buffer. It could copy directly from the wrapped input stream to the output byte array. It only needs to copy the initial bytes from its internal buffer.
Might be worth a pass to make sure nothing else is following this pattern.

There is one copy to internal slice of InputStreamSliceInput,  the advantage of doing it this way is to lower the count of real IO operation? For integer and small page, read from buffer is more efficient.

@aweisberg Currently block recoding relies on SliceInput. There's only one existing InputStreamSliceInput implementation, and unfortunately it is not very efficient. We had a discussion around that with Vic. I think we all agree that it has to be optimized. What do you think about doing it as a follow up?

It doesn't reduce the number of IO operations and will increase it in some cases. Basically if the size of the remaining bytes to read is > than the internal buffer size (or size > some multiple) it doesn't make sense to copy to the internal buffer. Pass the argument array to the wrapped stream along with the correct offset and length and do it directly.
Agree it should be a followup. It's not even a change we would make to this repo.
What case is this? Is there a unit test for it (null, and empty?)
For zero row file without any stripe,  stripeOffsets is empty.  This is covered by test testInsertPartitionedBucketedTableFewRows

This is more complicated then it needs to be. I think it would be simpler if we just had the footer include an offset and a length. I think file formats should only be fancy and concise when space is at a premium, otherwise they should minimize how complex they are to interpret.
I just don't see the value in doing what ORC does. It's not the last word in file formats. Unless there is interoperability with the serialized form I think we should do something simple.

I looked at this with Andrii briefly. I don't think this max is necessary?
Let's just go with this version. I don't want to block this over something so trivial. It's temporary data format.
nit: Maybe flushStripe?
I wonder if that should be an assertion
You can simply do Slices.wrappedBuffer(buffer, buffer.length - FOOTER_METADATA_SIZE, FOOTER_METADATA_SIZE).getInt(0)
Yeah, it feels like max is extra here
